title: Schema for Scoop manifest

anyOf.markdownDescription: - Use `Unknown`, which is the [official field defined by Scoop](https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/wiki/App-Manifests#required-properties), to indicate that the license cannot be determined.
- Use `Freeware`, which is the [official field defined by Scoop](https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/wiki/App-Manifests#required-properties), to indicate that the software is free to use forever.

- Use `Proprietary`, which is the [official field defined by Scoop](https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/wiki/App-Manifests#required-properties), to indicate that the software is a paid software(must pay to use)

- Use `Public Domain`, which is the [official field defined by Scoop](https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/wiki/App-Manifests#required-properties), to indicate that the software belongs to the public domain.

- Use `Shareware`, which is the [official field defined by Scoop](https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/wiki/App-Manifests#required-properties), to indicate that the software is free to try, but must pay eventually.

license.title: Software License
license.markdownDescription:
- Specify the license or type field of the software
- If different files have different licenses, separate the licenses with a comma `,`
- If the entire application is dual-licensed, use `|`
- https://spdx.org/licenses
- https://opensource.org/license

identifier.title: License Identifier
identifier.markdownDescription:

- If the entire application is dual-licensed, use `|`

- https://opensource.org/license

url.title: License URL
url.markdownDescription: - Specify the URL of the software license.

notes.title: Notes
notes.markdownDescription: - English notes after installing the software.

url_validation.errorMessage: It must be a valid http/https URL

url.title: Download URL
url.markdownDescription:
- The URL of the file to be downloaded
- If there are multiple URLs, an array can be used.
```json
  "url": [
      "http://example.com/file1.zip",
      "http://example.com/file2.zip"
  ]
  ```
- If you need to change the file name of the download URL, you can add `#/dl.7z` at the end of the URL. For example:
```json
  "url": "http://example.org/program.exe#/dl.7z"
  ```
- Scoop will download program.exe, but save it as dl.7z, and then automatically extract it using 7-Zip.

hash.title: Hash of the download file
hash.markdownDescription:
- The hash of the downloaded file.
- The default is `SHA256`.
- You can also use `SHA512`, `SHA1`, or `MD5` by prefixing the string with `sha512:`, `sha1:`, or `md5:`, respectively.

architecture.title: Architecture information
architecture.markdownDescription:
- The architecture information of the program.
- Architecture can be used to wrap differences

else.errorMessage: At least one of 64bit, 32bit, or arm64 must be defined in the architecture.

extract_dir.title: Extract specified directory only
extract_dir.markdownDescription:
- If the value of the url property points to a compressed package, Scoop will extract all content by default.
  - Compressed package types: `.zip`/`.7z`/`.tar`/`.gz`/`.lzma`/`.lzh`
- If the `extract_dir` property is defined, Scoop will only extract the specified directory defined in `extract_dir`.

extract_to.title: Extract content to specified directory
extract_to.markdownDescription:
- If the value of the url property points to a compressed package, Scoop will extract all content to the directory defined by `extract_to`
  - Compressed package types: `.zip`/`.7z`/`.tar`/`.gz`/`.lzma`/`.lzh`
- If url is an array with multiple compressed packages, `extract_to` should also be an array with the same order as url

env_add_path.title: Add the specified directory to the PATH environment variable
env_add_path.markdownDescription:
- Add the specified directory to the PATH environment variable (current user)
- If the `--global` or `-g` parameter is used during installation, the directory will be added to the PATH environment variable (system level)

env_set.title: Set environment variables
env_set.markdownDescription:
- Set one or more environment variables (current user)
- If the `--global` or `-g` parameter is used during installation, the variables will be set in the system environment variables (system level)

then.errorMessage: Property names cannot be empty strings

name.title: Module name
name.markdownDescription: - The name of the module, which should match at least one file in the extract directory for PowerShell to recognize it as a module

then.errorMessage: Missing two required values: program name, alias (shim)

bin.title: Program (executable or script) string or string array
bin.markdownDescription:
- A string or array of strings representing programs (executables or scripts) to be made available on the user's PATH
- A two-dimensional array can be used to create an alias shim that uses a different name from the real executable and optionally passes arguments to it
- The inner array must contain at most three strings: program name, alias, arguments (optional)
- Example 1: Scoop will create a shim named `a`, so you can run a.exe by typing `a`
```json
  "bin": "a.exe"
  ```
- Example 2: Same as Example 1, but Scoop creates two shims: `a` and `b`
```json
  "bin": ["a.exe", "b.exe"]
  ```
- Example 3: Same as Example 2, but the shims are named `ax` and `bx`
```json
  "bin": [
    ["a.exe", "ax"], 
    ["b.exe", "bx"]
  ]
  ```
- Example 4: Same as Example 3, but running the shims will automatically pass `--config $dir/config.json`
```json
  "bin": [
    ["a.exe", "ax", "--config $dir/config.json"], 
    ["b.exe", "bx", "--config $dir/config.json"]
  ]
  ```

shortcuts.title: Some shortcuts added to the Start menu
shortcuts.markdownDescription:
- Specifies shortcuts to be added to the Start menu, placed in the `Scoop Apps` folder
- Each array can contain up to four values:
    1. Required: path to the target file
    2. Required: name of the shortcut; subdirectories are supported: `aaa\bbb`
    3. Optional: launch arguments
    4. Optional: path to the icon file

items.markdownDescription: - Required: path to the target file
- Required: name of the shortcut; subdirectories are supported: `aaa\bbb`
- Optional: path to the icon file

then.errorMessage: Missing second required value: shortcut name
Missing two required values: target file path, shortcut name

persist.title: Persisted data
persist.markdownDescription:
- Scoop will persist the specified directories and files.
- Note: Scoop creates directory junctions by default; if you need file-level linking, create the file first in your install script.
- Example 1: Directory junction: `$dir\data` => `$persist_dir\data`
```json
  "persist": "data"
  ```
- Example 2: Same as Ex.1 but multiple items
```json
  "persist": ["data", "config.json"]
  ```
- Example 3: Same as Ex.2 but with custom target names
```json
  "persist": [
    ["app\\data", "userData"], 
    ["app\\config.json", "config.json"]
  ]
  ```

items.markdownDescription: - Original file or directory to persist
- Target location for the persisted data, supports subdirectories: `aaa\bbb`

then.errorMessage: Missing second required value: target location for the persisted data
Missing two required values: original file or directory to persist, target location for the persisted data

pre_install.title: Pre-install script
pre_install.markdownDescription:
- Commands to be executed before installing the application
- Execution order: `pre_install` -> `installer` -> `post_install`
- Available functions:
    - appdir: Reference another exclusive application.
For example, to check if another application is installed, you can use "if (Test-Path "$(appdir otherapp)\current\otherapp.exe") { ... }"
- Available variables:
    - $app: Application name (manifest name)
    - $architecture: CPU architecture of the installed application, such as 64bit/32bit/arm64
    - $cmd: Currently running subcommand, such as uninstall/update/install
    - $fname: Downloaded file name (may be multiple files, needs to be treated as an array unless you are sure url is not an array)
    - $global: If the value is $true, it is installed globally
    - $manifest: Deserialized manifest (PowerShell object), such as @{version=1.2.3; description=xxx;...}
    - $version: Version being installed, such as 1.2.3
    - $dir: Application installation directory (actual version number directory)
    - $persist_dir: Data persistence directory
    - $bucketsdir: Scoop buckets directory, such as D:\scoop\buckets
    - $bucket: Name of the bucket to which the currently installed application belongs
    - $cachedir: Scoop cache directory
    - $configFile: Path to Scoop configuration
    - $globaldir: Global installation directory
    - $modulesdir: Scoop modules directory
    - $original_dir: Application installation directory (actual version number directory)
    - $scoopdir: Scoop directory

installer.title: Installer configuration
installer.markdownDescription:
- Configuration for running non-MSI installers
- Called during scoop install and scoop update
- Execution order: `pre_install` -> `installer` -> `post_install`

file.markdownDescription:
- Executable file for the installer
- Defaults to the last downloaded URL if not specified
- Required if specified in uninstaller

script.markdownDescription:
- Execute as an installer instead of a file
- Available variables in the script:
    - $fname: downloaded file(s) (may be an array; treat as array unless you are sure url is not an array)
    - $manifest: validated manifest reference
    - $architecture: 64bit/32bit/arm64
    - $dir: installation directory

args.markdownDescription:
- Array of arguments to pass to the installer
- Optional property

keep.markdownDescription:
- Set to true if the installer should be kept after running (e.g., for future uninstallation)
- If omitted or set to any other value, the installer will be deleted after running

post_install.title: Post-install script
post_install.markdownDescription:
- Commands executed after the application is installed
- Execution order: `pre_install` -> `installer` -> `post_install`
- Note: At this point, Scoop has already completed persist, so if you need to create files for persist, do it before this (in pre_install)
- Available functions:
    - appdir: Reference another exclusive application.
For example, to check if another application is installed, you can use "if (Test-Path "$(appdir otherapp)\current\otherapp.exe") { ... }"
- Available variables:
    - $app: Application name (manifest name)
    - $architecture: CPU architecture of the installed application, e.g. 64bit/32bit/arm64
    - $cmd: Current running subcommand, e.g. uninstall/update/install
    - $fname: Downloaded file name (may be multiple files, treat as array unless you are sure url is not an array)
    - $cfg: Scoop configuration (PowerShell object), e.g. {SCOOP_BRANCH, SCOOP_REPO}
    - $global: If value is $true, then it's a global installation
    - $manifest: Deserialized manifest (PowerShell object), e.g. @{version=1.2.3; description=xxx;...}
    - $version: Version being installed, e.g. 1.2.3
    - $dir: Application installation directory (current directory)
    - $persist_dir: Data persistence directory
    - $bucketsdir: Scoop buckets directory, e.g. D:\scoop\buckets
    - $bucket: Name of the bucket to which the currently installed application belongs
    - $cachedir: Scoop cache directory
    - $configFile: Path to Scoop configuration
    - $globaldir: Global installation directory
    - $modulesdir: Scoop modules directory
    - $original_dir: Application installation directory (actual version number directory)
    - $scoopdir: Scoop installation directory

pre_uninstall.title: Pre-uninstall script
pre_uninstall.markdownDescription:
- Execute commands before uninstalling the application
- Execution order: `pre_uninstall` -> `uninstaller` -> `post_uninstall`
- Available functions:
    - appdir: Reference another exclusive application.
For example, to check if another application is installed, you can use "if (Test-Path "$(appdir otherapp)\current\otherapp.exe") { ... }"
- Available variables:
    - $app: Application name (manifest name)
    - $architecture: CPU architecture of the installed application, such as 64bit/32bit/arm64
    - $cmd: Currently running subcommand, such as uninstall/update/install
    - $global: If the value is $true, it is globally installed
    - $manifest: Deserialized manifest (PowerShell object), such as @{version=1.2.3; description=xxx;...}
    - $version: Version being installed, such as 1.2.3
    - $dir: Application installation directory (actual version number directory)
    - $persist_dir: Data persistence directory
    - $bucketsdir: Scoop buckets directory, such as D:\scoop\buckets
    - $bucket: Name of the bucket to which the currently installed application belongs
    - $cachedir: Scoop cache directory
    - $configFile: Path to Scoop configuration
    - $globaldir: Global installation directory
    - $modulesdir: Scoop modules directory
    - $original_dir: Application installation directory (actual version number directory)
    - $scoopdir: Directory where Scoop is located

uninstaller.title: Uninstaller configuration
uninstaller.markdownDescription:
- Configuration for running non-MSI uninstallers
- Called during scoop uninstall and scoop update
- Execution order: `pre_uninstall` -> `uninstaller` -> `post_uninstall`

script.markdownDescription:
- Execute as an uninstaller rather than a file
- Variables available in the script: 
    - $fname: downloaded file (there may be multiple files, which need to be handled as an array unless you are sure the url is not an array)
    - $manifest: verified manifest reference
    - $architecture: 64bit/32bit/arm64
    - $dir: installation directory

args.markdownDescription:
- Array of arguments to pass to the uninstaller
- Optional property

post_uninstall.title: Post-uninstall script
post_uninstall.markdownDescription:
- Used to execute commands after uninstalling the application
- Execution order: `pre_uninstall` -> `uninstaller` -> `post_uninstall`
- Available functions:
    - appdir: Reference another exclusive application.
For example, to check if another application is installed, you can use "if (Test-Path \"$(appdir otherapp)\\current\\otherapp.exe\") { ... }"
- Available variables:
    - $app: Application name (manifest name)
    - $architecture: CPU architecture of the installed application, such as 64bit/32bit/arm64
    - $cmd: The currently running subcommand, such as uninstall/update/install
    - $cfg: Scoop configuration (PowerShell object), such as {SCOOP_BRANCH, SCOOP_REPO}
    - $global: If the value is $true, it is installed globally
    - $manifest: Deserialized manifest (PowerShell object), such as @{version=1.2.3; description=xxx;...}
    - $version: The version being installed, such as 1.2.3
    - $dir: Application installation directory (actual version number directory)
    - $persist_dir: Data persistence directory
    - $bucketsdir: Scoop buckets directory, such as D:\scoop\buckets
    - $bucket: The name of the bucket to which the currently installed application belongs
    - $cachedir: Scoop cache directory
    - $configFile: Path to Scoop configuration
    - $globaldir: Global installation directory
    - $modulesdir: Scoop modules directory
    - $original_dir: Application installation directory (actual version number directory)
    - $scoopdir: Scoop directory

checkver.title: Version check configuration
checkver.markdownDescription:
- Application maintainers and developers can use the bin/checkver tool to check for updates to the application
- String: RegEx to find the version on the homepage
- Object: More rich configuration

url.markdownDescription: - URL of the page where the version is located

- re is an alias for regex
- RegEx to find the version on the homepage

regex.markdownDescription: - RegEx to find the version on the homepage

jsonpath.markdownDescription: - Use a JSON endpoint with a JSONPath expression to retrieve the version, you can use dot notation or bracket notation.

jp.markdownDescription:
- jp is an alias for jsonpath
- Use a JSON endpoint with a JSONPath expression to retrieve the version, you can use dot notation or bracket notation.

xpath.markdownDescription: - XPath expression to find the version on the homepage

reverse.markdownDescription: - If set to true, it matches the last occurrence (default is the first occurrence)

replace.markdownDescription: - Replace the matched value with the computed value

anyOf.markdownDescription: - Replace the matched value with `${1}.${2}.${3}.${4}${5}${6}`, where `${1}` represents the first match group, `${2}` represents the second match group, and so on.

useragent.markdownDescription: - User-Agent used to fetch the webpage content

script.markdownDescription: - PowerShell script to track multiple links

anyOf.markdownDescription: - If the homepage is a GitHub repository homepage, you can use the "github" string as the checkver configuration

autoupdate_url.title: Software download URL
autoupdate_url.markdownDescription:
- It is usually dynamic and includes version variables such as: `$version`
- For example: `https://github.com/owner/repo/releases/download/v$version/xxx.exe`

autoupdate_hash.markdownDescription: - Define how to get the hash for the software download

url.markdownDescription: - URL template to download the RDF/JSON file or extract the hash

regex.markdownDescription:
- Alias: find
RegEx expression to extract the hash

find.markdownDescription:
- Alias: regex
RegEx expression to extract the hash

oneOf.markdownDescription: - Get the hash generated by GitHub automatically, for more details, please refer to [GitHub blog](https://github.blog/changelog/2025-06-03-releases-now-expose-digests-for-release-assets/)
- Extract the hash from a plain text file or web page using RegEx (default, can be omitted)
- Extract the hash from a JSON file using JSONPath
- Extract the hash from an XML file using XPath
- Extract the hash from an RDF file
- Extract the hash from a Metalink header file or .meta4 file
- Download the application file and hash it locally (fallback)

description.title: App Description
description.markdownDescription: - A brief description of the software.

homepage.title: Homepage
homepage.markdownDescription: - Homepage or repository URL of the app

then.errorMessage: If it is the root domain of the official website, please end with '/'

depends.title: Dependencies
depends.markdownDescription:
- Dependencies of the app
- Missing dependencies will be automatically installed before the app is installed
- If a dependency is optional, please use the `suggest` property

suggest.title: Suggested Dependencies
suggest.markdownDescription:
- Suggested dependencies of the app
- If any of the suggested dependencies are already installed, the feature will be considered as **implemented**, and the user will not see any suggestions

^.+$.markdownDescription:
- If any of the suggested dependencies are already installed, the feature will be considered as **implemented**, and the user will not see any suggestions
- If it is an array, it means that if any of the dependencies in the array are installed, the feature will be considered as **implemented**

then.errorMessage: It must be an object with non-empty string keys

innosetup.markdownDescription: - If the installer is based on `InnoSetup`, set it to `true`

autoupdate.title: Auto Update
autoupdate.markdownDescription:
- It will automatically update the manifest via [Github Actions](https://github.com/abgox/abyss/blob/main/.github/workflows/excavator.yml)
 - Scoop can install specific versions using `scoop install AppName@1.2.3`
 - The prerequisite is that `url` in the `autoupdate` of the manifest can only contain the following [version variables](https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/wiki/App-Manifest-Autoupdate#version-variables)
    - `$version`
    - `$majorVersion`,`$minorVersion`,`$patchVersion`,`$buildVersion`,`$preReleaseVersion`
    - `$dotVersion`,`$dashVersion`,`$underscoreVersion`,`$cleanVersion`
    - `$matchHead`,`$matchTail`

architecture.title: Auto Update Architecture
architecture.markdownDescription:
- Define the architecture for auto update
- Architecture can be used to wrap differences
